thread.title: NFL kicking in crisis: Owners asked for this mess
thread.title_full: NFL kicking in crisis: Owners asked for this mess | New York Post

author: Bart Hubbuch
title: NFL kicking in crisis: Owners asked for this mess
text:
Can anyone in this league kick field goals?
With just a handful of exceptions, kicker is a position firmly in crisis throughout the NFL after yet another blizzard of missed field goals and extra points.
Josh Scobee set the tone last Thursday with two missed field goals on his way to the unemployment lin e that cost the Steelers a winnable game against Baltimore, and the trend never let up as the weekend featured 12 more missed field goals and four missed extra points.
There already have been 38 missed field goals, and Week 4 isn’t even over yet.
What in the world is going on here?
The early theory is the owners’ decision to move the extra-point spot back to the 15-yard line — thereby turning what had been an automatic play into a 33-yard attempt that is no gimme — has ended up working too well and thoroughly spooked the league’s kickers.
That theory was endorsed by former Jets kicker Jay Feely, who explained the intensified pressure kickers are feeling this season.
The Saints’ Zach Hocker reacts after missing a field goal at the end of regulation on Sunday night. Photo: AP “Extra points used to be in-game practice,” Feely wrote on Twitter. “You didn’t have to worry about the result (it was a given), which allowed you to focus on your form and get grooved in during the game.
“[They were] somewhat of a confidence-builder, like throwing a couple screen [passes] early for a QB,” Feely continued. “Now, the pressure is bigger for extra points than even [field goals] because there is zero room for error (100 percent success is demanded). The pressure intensifies, and it negatively impacts FG performance as well.”
Zach Hocker missed from 30 yards, off the left upright, at the end of regulation for the Saints (though that was rendered moot by Drew’ Brees 80-yard TD to C.J. Spiller in overtime).
Jaguars kicker Jason Myers failed twice to beat the Colts, missing a potential game-winning 53-yarder wide right with one second left in regulation and a 48-yarder in overtime of a 16-13 loss. Bucs rookie kicker Kyle Brindza missed field goals of 29 and 43 yards.
Of course, not everyone is afflicted. The Chiefs’ Cairo Santos nailed a franchise-record seven field goals in Kansas City’s 36-21 loss to the Bengals on Sunday, and the Ravens’ Justin Tucker, Adam Vinatieri (a.k.a Mr. Clutch) of the Colts and the Bears’ Robbie Gould all nailed tries from 50-plus yards in close wins.
But if the owners’ goal was to put some mystery back into the kicking experience (and it was), then they’ve already succeeded beyond their wildest dreams.
Additional reporting by Steve Serby
